etymologies: late Middle English (in the sense ‘residue of dregs after evaporation or pressing of a semiliquid substance’): via Latin from Greek magma (from massein ‘knead’)

definitions: hot fluid or semifluid material below or within the earth's crust from which lava and other igneous rock is formed on cooling

examples.text: when red-hot magma comes into contact with seawater, an explosion results
basaltic magmas are normally expelled at the surface in a very hot and fluid state

shortDefinitions: hot fluid or semi-fluid material below or within earth's crust from which lava and other igneous rock is formed on cooling
